Keynote

Managing Async With RxJS 5

Managing asynchrony in web applications is challenging: Ajax, web sockets, user events, animations. It's very easy to make mistakes and waste system resources, especially in single page applications.

In this talk, we'll identify some of the ways most applications are wasting resources while managing async with common abstractions like promises and callbacks. We'll then talk about what RxJS is, and what Observables are, and how they can help you remedy these problems in your application. We'll go over how RxJS 5 relates to Angular, and show why it's such a powerful tool.

Pascal Precht Cofounder at Thoughtram

Pascal is a front-end engineer and a Angular Developer Expert nominated by Google. He created the angular-translate module, is an Angular contributor and also part of the Angular Docs Authoring team.

TypeScript 2.1 + Angular 2: Better Together

TypeScript has become the tool of choice in writing both Angular 2 and apps. Does this mean you’ll need to learn a completely new language? No! TypeScript builds upon JavaScript as it exists today and in the future, building on what you know now and bringing you future features today.

Come see how easy TypeScript is to introduce to a project today and how the team is pushing the language forward.

Sani Yusuf Co-Organiser Of Ionic UK, Founder Of Haibrid

Sani is a Co-Organiser of the Ionic UK community and writes and creates content around Ionic. He is a Developer, Writer & Trainer and runs a startup called Haibrid that uses cross-platform mobile development techniques to create mobile solutions. When he is not coding, Sani likes to spend time contributing to the tech community and recently travelled the world for 8 months across 12 cities in 3 continents evangelising on mobile

A toolbox

Our craft requires a large toolbox of utils, gadgets and techniques. As all professionals we spend a lot of time refining which items go into our personal toolbox.

This is the story of my toolbox evaluation and what I've learned from working as part of the Angular team

Optimizing Angular 2 apps for production

When it comes to Angular applications, good resolutions on performances mean faster and lighter. There is a number of technics which can improve speed: bundling, tree shaking, ahead of time compilation, lazy loading.

In this talk, we’ll learn more about each of them, and we’ll see them in action on a sample application

Building mobile apps with Angular 2 and NativeScript

NativeScript is a free and open source JavaScript framework for building native iOS, Android, and Windows Phone apps. Add to that Angular 2.0 with TypeScript and you will get a truly amazing combination. But I know what you’re thinking: another way of building apps? What makes NativeScript special? Here are a few cool things:

  • Direct access to native APIs—no plugins required. Want to create a file on Android? Run new java.io.File()—in JavaScript!
  • Completely native performance through the use of a JavaScript bridge natively available on all three mobile platforms.
  • Cross-platform libraries for common use cases. Need to call a JSON API? Run http.getJSON
  • Style native apps using CSS. Yep, that’s actually a thing.

Curious about how it all works? Come learn! Architectures will be explained; apps will be built; and fun will be had by all

Sebastian Witalec Technical Evangelist at Telerik

Sebastian Witalec is a Technical Evangelist for Telerik with over 8 years of experience in software engineering and architecture. Sebastian has passion for all types of technologies. However in the last few years his focus shifted towards cross platform Mobile development where he gained experience with Apache Cordova and NativeScript (a member of the team). He is always happy to learn about the new stuff and to pass the knowledge as far as his voice (or the wire) can take him. Sebastian is based in London, UK actively working with various Dev communities in the area. When not acting techie he is a massive football fan/player (probably bigger at heart than skills).

Reactive Music Apps in Angular 2 and ngrx/store

Angular 2 combined with RxJS, @ngrx/store, and Immutable.js is a fantastic platform for reactive web applications. If we then add hot loading and the Web Audio API to the mix, we have something truly exciting: A platform for reactive music creation.

This talk is about creating musical systems on the Angular platform. We’ll see how we can model an asynchronous process that generates music right there in the browser and allows the user to control it on the fly. It’s a really enjoyable way to learn reactive Angular application development.

Ari Lerner Cofounder at Fullstack.io, Author of ng-book

Ari Lerner is an author and developer with more than 20 years of experience, as well as co-founder of Fullstack.io. He has been using AngularJS for a long time and is a recognized expert in the field. He co-runs the ng-newsletter, speaks at conferences, constantly produces content all about AngularJS, has recently released Riding Rails with AngularJS, and teaches in-person classes at Hack Reactor. He constantly speaks about AngularJS and more, including talks and workshops such as Angular on Mobile, Powering physical interfaces with Angular at ngConf, and Workshop: AngularJS for beginners.

Getting Started in Angular 2 with Angular-CLI

Watch a live code session of an Angular 2 Angular-CLI application and see how easy it is to use this new framework and why it is great for quickly prototyping ideas and why it is being used to scale across large scale organizations.

We'll discuss the features of the CLI, the Angular 2 component structure, the newest new router, using directives, and template-driven forms.

Across the universe - Server side rendering with Angular Universal

Angular 2 is designed to be agnostic about the runtime environment. This means that the same application can be deployed to different environments like browsers, servers or even native devices.

In this talk we will learn how to leverage this power using Angular Universal, and deploy our front-end SPA on the server without modification.
We will also learn how to avoid accessing environment specific functions, like direct DOM access, etc.

Joe Eames Pluralsight author and Software Craftsmanship Evangelist

Organizer of ng-conf, Front end developer, Pluralsight author and Software Craftsmanship Evangelist.

Angular 2 Change Detection and Performance Optimization

In Angular 1 the main reason for performance issues was the digest loop ($apply method). Angular 2.0 brings an entirely new approach called change detection (ChangeDetectorRef class).

In this session I am going to speak about the change detection mechanism, how it works to update the screen and how to use it to improve the performance for high frequency data changes.

AoT and the New Angular Compiler

One of the amazing features offered by Angular 2 is Ahead of Time template compilation. It comes with a lot of benefits, such as static analysis of your application templates, runtime performance benefits, and reduced production payload size.

In this talk, we are going to learn about ngc - the new Angular Compiler, discuss the internal mechanisms that make it tick, and discover how our apps can benefit from it.

Angular 2 and GraphQL - Handling server data with Apollo

Angular 2 has officially been released, and the Angular team has been focusing on making it a great platform for building Progressive Web Apps.

A critical component of a progressive web app is the smart use of sending data through the network for better application performance and user experience.

GraphQL and the Apollo-Angular integration help get data in front of users instantly, efficiently and easily

Angular, MobX, happiness.

Imagine the magic of Angular 1 digest, but extremely performant and smart.

MobX detects changes in plain objects, allowing you to react automatically to changes you make on observable attributes, and define computed values

In this talk I will introduce MobX and its benefits, and the ng2-mobx library I wrote to connect it seamlessly to Angular

Building Mobile Apps Progressively With Ionic

With multiple competing mobile eco systems to worry about, it is always important to choose an efficient solution for creating your mobile Apps

With the exciting prospects of Progressive Web Apps taking the web & mobile web world by storm, it can be quite challenging to fit a current mobile setup to work with Progressive Web Apps

This talk will showcase how you can create a mobile app for Android, IOS, WIndows with 100% the same code & same project and still have it work as a Progressive Web application without any change

Angular Material 2

Components are a critical part of the Angular Platform.

Angular Material aims to give you the components you need to build a quality app in no time at all.

In this talk, you will hear the latest status update directly from the team and get a sneak peek at what is coming.

Redux Data Flow with Angular 2

There are many ways to create data flows in Angular 2. One of those ways is the architectural pattern called Redux.

Redux is a small library which introduces a unidirectional data flow and a predictable state container that scales.

In this session we will deep dive into Redux concepts and how to apply them in Angular 2 apps

Angular Web Worker - Building Super Responsive UI

HTML5 brings the power of web workers. However, managing a web worker is a tedious and error prone work

Angular 2 has a built-in support for running application logic inside a secondary web worker. Angular does the magic of marshaling requests between DOM and the application worker and let you focus on building super responsive UI components while enjoying the power of parallel code execution.

During this session we will cover the architecture and details behind the Angular 2 web worker support

Dynamic content creation in Angular 2

Ahead of Time compilation is what the Angular team recommends these days.

In this talk we will try to figure out what is that little price we pay when we choose AoT over JiT. In a dynamic compilation context, we will take a brief de-tour reviewing the compiler, understanding the performance penalties of runtime compilation and why AoT is preferred over JiT even if loosing the ability to dynamically create components.

We will clarify the difference between creating and instantiating components, how ComponentFactory and the Injector align, and go over scenarios where we might want to use it.

Just before giving up on JiT we will wonder off contemplating on futuristic ideas such as combining AoT, JiT & lazy loading for best of all world or maybe using the server as a compilation service...

Q&A Panel

Lightning talks

Lightning talks about various topics from community speakers.
